body.title: 'It Was Not Human': UFO Whistleblower Details Recovery Of Giant Egg-Like Object
body.description: Barber told NewsNation’s Ross Coulthart that the object looked like a large white egg and was about the size of an SUV. The ...
body.article_content:
LOADING ERROR LOADING

A former Air Force Special Operations airman told NewsNation that he worked for a secret unit that retrieved debris that he believes was from crashed unidentified flying objects.

“Just visually looking at the object on the ground, you could tell that it was extraordinary and anomalous,” Jacob Barber, who said he had worked in both official and unofficial capacities for the U.S. government, told the network. “It was not human.”

Advertisement

Barber told NewsNation’s Ross Coulthart that the object looked like a large white egg and was about the size of an SUV. The UFO ― which the U.S. government now called UAPs, or unidentified aerial phenomena ― had no engine and no thermal signature.

“It’s inconsistent with anything I’d ever seen before,” he said. “I can also tell you that the reaction by my team, we all knew we were dealing with something extraordinary.”

Barber said it was later confirmed to him that the object was from a “nonhuman intelligence,” but doesn’t know what it was.

Advertisement

He said he also picked up what he called an “eightgon,” which he described as “a flying disc with what looked like eight delineated sections.” Barber described feeling “odd” and growing more emotional as he got closer to the “eightgon” object.

“I felt like something connected with me,” he said. “I felt like something had tuned in to me and my soul and was providing me some sense of guidance on what to do and how profound what I was doing was. It was so overwhelming that I began to cry.”

NewsNation also said it independently obtained footage of an egg-shaped object being moved by helicopter:

Advertisement

While few details can be seen, the object isn’t dissimilar to some of those seen in flight in prior videos from other whistleblowers, footage later confirmed by the Pentagon as authentic.

One, called the “Tic Tac” because of its similarity to the mint candies, shows a white object with no visible wings or engines moving rapidly through the sky as pilots react in awe.

Advertisement

There has been no clear answer as to what the objects are, but some observers have noted that there are more down-to-earth explanations for them, such as drones or balloons, in some cases of potentially foreign origin and with advanced ― but not alien ― technology.

body.title: Gardner library to host UFOs in New England presentation - here's what will be discussed
body.description: Paranormal investigator Ronny LeBlanc will discuss UFOs in New England at the Levi Heywood Memorial Library. What to know ...
body.article_content:
It will be a close encounter of the informative and entertaining kind when a local paranormal investigator shares his experiences at the Levi Heywood Memorial Library in Gardner.

Ronny LeBlanc, who starred on the "Expedition Bigfoot" series on the Discovery Channel for several season and appears regularly on "Paranormal Caught on Camera" the Travel Channel, will discuss the phenomena of unidentified flying objects in New England at the library on Wednesday, Jan. 22.

LeBlanc, who lives in Leominster and is the author of two "Monsterland" books, said he had been unaware that Central Massachusetts had been such a hotbed of UFO activity until he began doing research for his first book.

Ronny LeBlanc, a renowned Leominster-based paranormal investigator, will discuss "UFOs in New England" at the Levi Heywood Memorial Library on Wednesday, Jan. 22. The event, which will begin at 6:00 p.m., is free and open to the public.

"There were rumors that Fort Devens, believe it or not, had a crash-retrieval program for UFOs, and then I heard from people personally that they had heard Fort Devens had a supposed recovered UFO, which kind of blew me away," said LeBlanc. "For whatever reason, this area has had a long history of this stuff."

ADVERTISEMENT

In fact, LeBlanc said, the very first UFO sighting ever reported occured in Massachusetts in the 1600s, when Gov. James Winthrop claimed to have seen a strange light moving up and down in the sky over Charlestown. And people have been fascinated by the possibility of being visited by aliens ever since, he said.

"What are these things and why are people seeing these crafts?" LeBlanc wondered. "Not all of these people can be lying, and I think people are ready now for the truth to come out. There has to be life elsewhere."

UFOs in Ashburnham?

No discussion of UFOs in New England can be complete without including the "Andreasson Affair," a celebrated case concerning the alleged abduction of an Ashburnham woman by aliens in 1967. The incident, which was the subject of several books and a movie, concerned the experience of Betty Andreasson, who claimed to have been abducted from her Highland Ave. home, taken aboard a UFO, and experimented on by aliens.

More: An Ashburnham close encounter 50 years ago

ADVERTISEMENT

LeBlanc said the Andreasson incident one of UFOlogy's most interested cases because of how much serious investigation went into trying to find out exactly what happened.

"Through 1965 and 1967, during that time period, there were a lot of reports of flying saucers, but Betty's story was really compelling," LeBlanc said, adding that unusual phenomena seemed to follow Andreasson, who also lived for a time in Fitchburg and Leominster, throughout her life. "She passed several lie-detector tests, people witnessed an orange orb appear in the room while she was being interviewed, and another time people witnessed a gray alien materialize in the interview room and then disappear. There was some real strange stuff going on with her."

After Andreasson moved to Florida, according to LeBlanc, her husband reported seeing mysterious black helicopters hovering over the couple's home from time to time.

Recent drone sightings have renewed interest in UFOs

Recent reports of mystery drones flying over the East coast had sparked a renewed interest in UFOs, and LeBlanc said it was possible that some of the object in the skies could be of extraterrestrial origin. And he has a bold prediction for the year ahead.

ADVERTISEMENT

More: Officials investigate drone sightings spotted in New Jersey and other states

"I think we're going to find out we're not alone in 2025," he said.

The event, which will be held in the library's Greenwood Meeting Room at 6 p.m., is free and open to the public.

This article originally appeared on Gardner News: Levi Heywood Memorial Library to host UFOs in New England presentation

body.title: USAF soldier 'recovered egg-shaped UFO' for government as bizarre video emerges
body.description: Is this our first close-up look at a spacecraft from another world? Leading UFO pundit Ross Coulthart claims he has obtained ...
body.article_content:
An extraordinary video supposedly showed a crashed alien craft being recovered by a US Air Force helicopter has been released by a whistleblower.

The clip, which leading UAP pundit Ross Coulthart claims was secretly recorded by a member of the Pentagon’s secret UFO crash retrieval team, shows a 20-foot “egg-shaped” object suspended in a sling, apparently beneath a helicopter.

The footage chimes with a description given to Coulthart by former US Air Force mechanic Jacob Barber, who claims to have taken part in the retrieval of a similar craft. Barber says that he left the Air Force shortly after September 11, 2001, and established a “cover” identity as a civilian contractor.

Barber told Coulthart: “A lot of the work we did was on what I call ‘The Range,’ where the US government and its private partners used to test all kinds of things — weapon systems and resilience to weapon systems of certain craft — and so you see a lot of exciting things.”

But, although he witnessed tests of numerous advanced military aircraft prototypes, nothing could prepare him for his encounter with an anomalous craft that seemed to have no wings, windows, or propulsion system. “Just visually looking at the object on the ground, you could tell that it was extraordinary and anomalous. It was not human,” he said.

Barber says he was tasked with the retrieval of this strange object, and deployed a sling from his helicopter on the end of a 150-foot “long line” to carry it. His description of what he recovered that day sounds like no known type of aircraft.

“I saw an egg, a white egg,” he said. “There was no engine. There was no thermal signature. I was operating at night when I finally came in to pick it up. So, I’m working under night vision goggles at the time, and it was quite clear. I flipped them up, flipped them down and looked at it a couple of different ways.”

Image: Sky News Australia) Sky News Australia)

Following his experience, Barber says that it was confirmed to him by his superiors that the mysterious white “egg” was a craft built by “NHI,” (nonhuman intelligence). He went on to encounter several other apparently alien craft during his service with the USAF.

He continued: “There was another object. One was the egg, the other is what I called an ‘eightgon.’ The eightgon was essentially a flying disc with what looked like eight delineated sections when looking down.”

He says that he only ever saw the object from above, because his task was solely to pick them up from ‘The Range’ and deliver them top a secret USAF research facility. He has no concrete information on what the USAF was doing with these objects, but describes seeing “trans-medium” craft that appeared to be able to fly through the air but also to pass through solid matter.

Image: Getty Images) Getty Images)

Barber went on to say that some USAF personnel had been trained in a form of telepathy that enabled them to control these aircraft. “In the program, there was certainly a desire to explore the idea that perhaps UAP could be summoned, could be communicated with, could be controlled and could be persuaded to land, all by deploying people with psionic abilities to interface and communicate with the UAP,” he claimed.

These “psionic” phenomena around the UFOs affected Barber directly. On one occasion, he says, he had a quasi-religious experience while en route to pick up another one of the strange craft: “I felt like something connected with me,” he said.

“I felt like something had tuned in to me and my soul and was providing me some sense of guidance on what to do and how profound what I was doing was. It was so overwhelming that I began to cry.”

Image: AP) AP)

He adds that he began to fear for his life after seeing just how far Pentagon officials would go to maintain the cover-up of their contact with extraterrestrials. Asa result, he says, he has met with US senator Marco Rubio – Donald Trump’s incoming secretary of state – to share what he knows in hope of getting some protection.

The footage itself, shown by Coulthart in a News Nation special over the weekend, has divided viewers. Some suggested that the “egg-shaped object” was simply an egg, and that the entire clip was an elaborate hoax.

With Donald Trump promising to lift the lid on other long-running conspiracy theories, such as the truth about the 1963 Kennedy assassination, the truth about Barber’s experiences could very soon be revealed.

body.title: 10 AI Language Learning Apps That Will Make You Fluent Faster
body.description: Learn languages faster with AI - Check out the best apps for immersive practice, pronunciation, and vocabulary building. Dr ...
body.article_content:
Learning a new language can feel like standing at the base of a towering mountain, unsure of where to begin or how to reach the summit. Maybe you’ve tried traditional methods—textbooks, flashcards, or even a few classes—only to find yourself stuck, frustrated, or losing motivation. The good news? Technology has come a long way, and with the rise of AI-powered language learning apps, you now have AI tools that adapt to your unique pace, preferences, and goals. These apps aren’t just about memorizing vocabulary; they’re designed to make the process interactive, personalized, and even fun.

In this guide by Dr Alex Young explore some of the best AI language learning apps available today, each offering its own approach to helping you master a new language. Whether you’re looking to improve your conversational skills, perfect your pronunciation, or simply make learning more engaging, there’s an app tailored for you. From gamified lessons to real-time feedback and immersive roleplays, these tools are reshaping how we approach language learning.

Top AI Language Learning Apps

TL;DR Key Takeaways : AI-powered language learning apps offer personalized, engaging, and accessible tools for improving fluency, pronunciation, and vocabulary.

Top apps like Shiken, Praktika, and Speak focus on conversational practice, while Duolingo and Babbel provide structured lessons and gamified experiences.

Budget-conscious learners may prefer affordable options like Univerbal or free tools like ChatGPT, though these may lack comprehensive features.

Specialized apps such as Eggbun and Pimsleur cater to specific needs, including Asian languages and audio-based learning.

Choosing the right app depends on your goals, with options ranging from immersive roleplays to vocabulary-building games and real-time feedback tools.

The integration of artificial intelligence (AI) into language learning has transformed the way people acquire new languages. AI-powered tools provide learners with personalized, efficient, and engaging experiences, catering to diverse learning styles and goals. These apps use advanced algorithms to enhance fluency, pronunciation, and vocabulary retention, making language learning more accessible than ever. Below is a brief exploration of the top AI language learning apps, their features, and how they can help you achieve your linguistic objectives according to Dr Alex Young.

1. Shiken

Shiken is a comprehensive platform that combines quizzes, exams, and courses with innovative AI technology. Its standout features include:

AI roleplays that simulate real-life conversations for immersive practice

that simulate real-life conversations for immersive practice Voice control and real-time translation for seamless interaction

and real-time translation for seamless interaction Detailed coaching reports and support from an AI tutor

With a subscription starting at $45 per year, Shiken offers a cost-effective solution for learners seeking a well-rounded language learning experience.

2. Praktika

Praktika uses generative AI avatars to create dynamic and personalized English learning sessions. Key features include:

Custom roleplays with instant translation to enhance comprehension

with instant translation to enhance comprehension Hints and guidance to support your progress

While its interactive approach is engaging, the annual subscription of $100 may be a consideration for those on a tighter budget.

3. Speak

Speak is tailored for learners who want to focus on improving their speaking and pronunciation skills. It offers:

Conversational practice with real-time feedback to refine your accent and fluency

However, its limited focus on grammar and writing may make it less suitable for those seeking a more comprehensive learning tool.

4. Duolingo (Geo)

Duolingo is widely recognized for its gamified, bite-sized lessons available in over 30 languages. Its AI-driven features include:

Engaging conversational roleplays to boost language retention

The free version provides substantial value, while the premium subscription, priced at $100 per year, unlocks additional features. Duolingo is ideal for learners who enjoy a playful and interactive approach to language acquisition.

10 Best AI Language Learning Apps

Here is a selection of other guides from our extensive library of content you may find of interest on AI language learning apps.

5. Babbel

Babbel focuses on structured lessons designed for real-world application. Its AI capabilities include:

Data-driven personalized exercises to target specific learning needs

While Babbel excels in practical language use, its relatively high subscription cost and varying content quality across different languages may be limiting factors for some learners.

6. TalkPal

TalkPal emphasizes conversational practice through real-life scenarios. Its features include:

Realistic AI voices for a more personalized learning experience

for a more personalized learning experience Interactive lessons with flexible subscription options

This app is particularly effective for learners aiming to enhance their speaking and listening skills.

7. ChatGPT

ChatGPT offers flexible conversational practice through customizable prompts. You can use it for:

Generating vocabulary lists quickly

Providing translation support for various languages

While it is free and highly adaptable, ChatGPT lacks structured lessons and progress tracking, which may limit its effectiveness for long-term learning goals.

8. Univerbal

Univerbal is designed to improve conversational skills with features such as:

Customizable topics to suit your interests

Real-time feedback to refine your speaking abilities

Its affordability makes it an appealing option for budget-conscious learners, though its limited language selection may not meet the needs of all users.

9. Tutor Lily

Tutor Lily focuses on developing speaking skills with features like:

Real-time feedback from AI language coaches

from AI language coaches Pronunciation assistance to improve clarity

However, its lack of emphasis on grammar and writing makes it best suited for learners prioritizing conversational practice.

10. Memrise

Memrise employs spaced repetition to help learners retain vocabulary effectively. Its features include:

Audio recordings by native speakers

Interactive lessons to reinforce learning

While it excels in vocabulary building, the free version offers limited conversational practice, which may require upgrading for a more comprehensive experience.

Additional AI Tools

Linguist

Linguist is designed to improve speaking, writing, and reading skills. Its key features include:

A personalized AI tutor for tracking progress and providing tailored feedback

However, its free options are limited, and it places less emphasis on listening skills, which may not suit all learners.

Lura

Lura is an AI-powered English tutor that uses advanced speech recognition to deliver personalized learning experiences. Its primary feature is:

Instant feedback to help refine pronunciation and grammar

This makes it a practical choice for learners seeking targeted improvements in specific areas.

Non-AI Tools

Rosetta Stone

Rosetta Stone combines immersive learning techniques with AI-powered speech recognition. It focuses on:

Building vocabulary through interactive exercises

Pronunciation practice to improve speaking skills

However, it provides limited feedback on incorrect answers, which may hinder deeper understanding.

Busuu

Busuu aligns its structured lessons with CEFR standards, offering a clear path for learners to track their progress. It also connects users with native speakers for practical language practice, making it a versatile option for learners at all levels.

Mondly

Mondly offers gamified lessons with AI chatbot integration. It emphasizes:

Improving pronunciation through interactive exercises

through interactive exercises Encouraging daily practice to build consistency

This app is particularly convenient for busy learners who prefer short, engaging sessions.

Eggbun Education

Eggbun specializes in Asian languages such as Korean, Chinese, and Japanese. Its gamified chatbot provides:

Cultural insights to deepen understanding

Conversational practice for real-world application

Pimsleur

Pimsleur focuses on audio-based learning with spaced repetition to build conversational fluency. Its 30-minute daily lessons are ideal for learners with limited time who want to develop practical speaking skills.

Drops

Drops gamifies vocabulary learning through fast-paced games. While it is effective for building a strong vocabulary foundation, its limited focus on grammar and conversational skills may not suit all learners.

Media Credit: Dr Alex Young

body.title: Sources: AI vision startup Metropolis is buying Oosto (formerly known as AnyVision) for just $125M
body.description: The general hype around all things AI is not lifting all boats: certain startups continue to struggle and are looking for ...
body.article_content:
The general hype around all things AI is not lifting all boats: certain startups continue to struggle and are looking for exits. In one of the latest developments, TechCrunch has heard from a reliable source that Metropolis, an AI-powered parking platform, is buying Oosto, the controversial computer vision company that used to be known as AnyVision. The source tells TechCrunch that the deal is valued at $125 million — just one-third of the $380 million that the startup had raised from investors over the years — and likely a fraction of its peak valuation.

Metropolis buying Oosto for $125 million are details that are also being reported in Israeli press. Last week, Globes broke the news that Oosto was up for sale. We understand that the two companies had already been working together prior to this deal, and that a large part of the transaction involves shares. We have reached out to both Metropolis and Oosto for further information and will update this post as we learn more.

If it completes, the sale will cap off a turbulent several years for Oosto.

As AnyVision, the company was one of a wave of computer vision startups building technology being used in controversial surveillance applications. Over the years, there were reports exposing which organizations were quietly using its technology and how the Israeli government tapped it to spy on Palestinians; other reports shed light on just how much data the company was able to collect. The bad publicity led to the company losing Microsoft as a key strategic investor, although other investors were ready to double down. In 2021, AnyVision, pitching itself as an ethical AI company, raised a whopping $235 million led by SoftBank and Eldridge. Other backers of the company have included Lightspeed and Qualcomm, per PitchBook data.

Just months after the big SoftBank raise, AnyVision rebranded to Oosto and looked to pivot to more enterprise applications as it inked a research partnership with Carnegie Mellon. But it seems that the difficulties continued, with rounds of layoffs and Oosto parting ways with the university. Today’s report in Calcalist noted that it was not making more than $10 million in annual revenues.

It’s worth wondering whether some of Oosto’s problems might have been a question of timing. The last couple of years have seen big geopolitical shifts; AI entering the mainstream of public consciousness; and a new wave of AI companies like Anduril and Helsing that seem to be breaking through many taboos on building military, defense and (more euphemistically) “resilience” technology.

Would AnyVision (or Oosto) have appeared as controversial today as it did five years ago? Regardless, the rise and fall of Oosto can be seen as a memento mori for the newer wave of AI companies that are being funded today on very high hopes, but perhaps not very high revenues (let alone profits).

That brings us to Metropolis. It, too, is focused on computer vision, but focus is perhaps the operative word here: its square aim is to build AI-based systems for parking, automatically tracking cars when they enter or leave a space and charging accordingly. In 2023, Metropolis raised $1.7 billion in financing and other investment, most of which was used to make a $1.5 acquisition of another parking technology specialist called SP Plus. Whether it will be using Oosto to continue building out that business, or to extend into a wider range of mobility and other applications, remains to be seen.

“Tech-wise this acquisition makes the perfect sense,” Avihai Michaeli, an investment banking advisor based in Tel Aviv, told TechCrunch. “Both Metropolis and Oosto (formerly known as AnyVision Tech) are key players in the AI-driven computer vision and security solutions space, with applications that enhance urban management, public safety, and automation. Both companies focus on leveraging cutting-edge technology to create safer, smarter, and more efficient environments through artificial intelligence and data analytics.” He added that the current war in Israel right now has made it challenging for some Israeli companies looking to raise money or do other business, which could have also played a role here.

body.title: Appalachian Ghost Tours investigate Hinton museum
body.description: Now, it stands as a museum, and a part of Summers County history. On Jan. 18, the museum partnered with Appalachian Ghosts ...
body.article_content:
HINTON, W.Va. (WVVA) - The Campbell-Flannagan-Murrell House was built in the late 1800s, serving as a home for generations of a Hinton family, as well as as a general store for a time.

Now, it stands as a museum, and a part of Summers County history. On Jan. 18, the museum partnered with Appalachian Ghosts Tours to offer a unique experience of history, culture, and potentially paranormal spirits with guided tours and an investigation.

Attempting to encounter spirits can require some technology, and as the Executive Director of Appalachian Ghost Tours, Mark Covey, explained, special equipment as well as ordinary objects can get the job done.

“We have EMF meters that will go off if, like, an electric spike gets near you. We have REM pods that basically do the same thing, but they stay in a stationary area and they will make a lot of noise,” said Covey. “We have cat balls that, you know, you wouldn’t think would be anything, but they will just be sitting in there on something solid and they will start to light up.”

Although the house is simply a museum by day, even those familiar with the home have experienced unexplained happenings.

“There’s been times when I’ve been in this house by myself and heard footsteps and nobody’s been in the house, so yeah, I think that there’s something going on, but I don’t feel that it’s malicious in any way,” said Carol Jackson, President of the Board of Trustees over the Campbell-Flannagan-Murrell House Museum.

This event is part of an ongoing effort for more paranormal tourism in Appalachia, bringing attention to smaller communities that are rich with folklore and paranormal history.

“Southern West Virginia is absolutely overflowing with the haunted stories, the paranormal, there is an energy here like no other and there is a history here like no other,” explained Pamela Huff, a member of Appalachian Ghost Tours.

For more information on the museum, you can view their website or Facebook page, and to keep up to date with Appalachian Ghost Tours, click here.

body.title: 5 stunning ways retinal scans can predict stroke risk
body.description: Discover how retinal vascular fingerprint analysis is revolutionizing stroke prediction through a simple eye scan, offering ...
body.article_content:
In a groundbreaking discovery that sounds like science fiction but is absolutely real, researchers have found that your eyes contain hidden signals that could predict your risk of having a stroke. This revolutionary finding isn’t just another medical study, it’s a potential game-changer in how we approach stroke prevention and early detection.

The incredible science behind retinal fingerprints

Scientists have identified 29 unique vascular indicators in your retina that serve as warning signs for stroke risk. These tiny blood vessels in your eyes create patterns as unique as your fingerprints, and their condition can reveal crucial information about your overall health. Within these indicators, 17 are density-related markers that can increase your stroke risk by up to 19% when altered. These changes are like tiny red flags waving in your eyes, signaling potential danger before other symptoms appear. The remaining indicators focus on the size and twistedness of blood vessels, with changes potentially raising stroke risk by nearly 20%. Think of these vessels as tiny roads in your eyes, their condition reflecting the health of your entire cardiovascular system.

Why this discovery is absolutely mind-blowing

Traditional stroke risk assessments often involve invasive procedures and expensive tests. But this new method requires nothing more than a specialized photograph of your eye. The implications are enormous, especially for communities where access to advanced medical testing is limited or cost-prohibitive.

The beauty of this breakthrough lies in its simplicity. During a routine eye exam, doctors can capture detailed images of your retina and analyze them for these crucial indicators. It’s painless, quick, and could potentially save countless lives through early detection.

The fascinating connection between your eyes and brain

Your retina isn’t just a window to your soul, it’s actually an extension of your brain. Every tiny blood vessel in your eye tells a story about the health of your brain’s blood vessels. This connection explains why changes in your retinal vasculature can predict stroke risk with remarkable accuracy.

What makes this discovery revolutionary

The research team analyzed data from over 45,000 participants. This massive study revealed that retinal analysis combined with basic demographic information could predict stroke risk as accurately as traditional methods.

What’s truly remarkable is how this technology could transform preventive healthcare. Imagine walking into your local eye clinic and getting a comprehensive stroke risk assessment during your regular eye exam. This isn’t just convenient, it’s revolutionary for global health care accessibility.

The global impact of this breakthrough

This discovery could dramatically change how we approach stroke prevention worldwide. In regions where advanced medical facilities are scarce, a simple eye scan could become a lifesaving tool. The technology could help identify at-risk individuals years before they might experience a stroke, allowing for early intervention and prevention strategies.

Healthcare providers are particularly excited about implementing this technology in primary care settings. It could become as routine as checking blood pressure, but with the potential to reveal much more detailed information about cardiovascular health.

What this means for the future of healthcare

The implications extend far beyond stroke prediction. Researchers believe similar retinal analysis could help predict other conditions like heart disease and dementia. This opens up endless possibilities for early detection and prevention of various diseases through simple eye examinations.

As technology continues to advance, we might see artificial intelligence systems analyzing these retinal images in real-time, providing instant risk assessments and recommendations. This could revolutionize how we approach preventive healthcare, making it more accessible and effective than ever before.

The discovery of retinal vascular fingerprints as predictors of stroke risk isn’t just a scientific breakthrough, it’s a glimpse into the future of medicine. It shows us that sometimes the most powerful diagnostic tools are hidden in plain sight, waiting to be understood and utilized. As this technology develops and becomes more widely available, it could transform how we approach disease prevention and ultimately save countless lives through early detection and intervention.

body.title: Scientists discover ancient 'sunken worlds' hidden beneath Earth's mantle under Pacific Ocean
body.description: Scientists uncover ancient crust hidden deep within Earth's mantle, revealing a 'sunken world' that challenges our ...
body.article_content:
Scientists have identified unexpected sections of Earth's crust deep inside the mantle. (Image: Canva)

The Earth’s mysteries never cease to amaze us. Recent discoveries have revealed ancient crust hidden deep within the mantle. This "sunken world" challenges our understanding of the planet's dynamic processes. What lies beneath could redefine geological history.

New Method Unveils Hidden Mantle Anomalies

Scientists have identified unexpected sections of Earth's crust deep inside the mantle. Using advanced seismographic imaging, researchers mapped these anomalies in unprecedented detail. The study, published in Scientific Reports, highlights unknown structures under areas with no tectonic activity.

Story continues below Advertisement Remove Ad

One key discovery was beneath Easter Island, where sunken crust sections were detected. Researchers believe these anomalies could be remnants of the mantle's creation. Alternatively, they might contain dense material formed over millions of years.

Read More: 'Moon at risk of huge damage': Earth's natural satellite added to endangered heritage list; here's why

Doctoral candidate Thomas Schouten from ETH Zurich said, "With the high-resolution model, we see anomalies everywhere. But their true nature is still unclear."

Revolutionary Techniques Offer Clearer Insight

Unlike traditional methods using isolated earthquake data, this research combines global seismographs into a cohesive model. Full-waveform inversion, the technique used, required the Piz Daint supercomputer in Switzerland to process vast datasets.

Co-author Thue Fichtner likened the discovery to medical imaging breakthroughs. "It’s like finding a new artery in an unexpected location," Fichtner said.

Despite similarities to known subducted slabs, the anomalies raise new questions. Further research will delve into their composition and origins. Scientists hope these findings will unlock deeper insights into Earth’s evolving structure.

body.title: RCSI’s precision medicine Master’s graduates are ready for the next evolution
body.description: The Master of Science in Technologies and Analytics in Precision Medicine is future-focused to equip graduates to meet the ...
body.article_content:
Precision medicine has gone far beyond a buzzy phrase and is now a reality in the treatment of certain diseases including cancer and a range of other chronic diseases. Personalising treatment through genetic profiling and data analysis, where treatments are tailored to an individual, should achieve the best possible outcomes for patients. However, this requires the fusion of many technologies and skill sets. RCSI’s state-of-the-art Masters programme in Technologies and Analytics in Precision Medicine (MScTAPM) aims to address this skills gap and produce the biological data scientists that the pharmaceutical industry say are vital if precision medicine is to become the norm.

Leading RCSI's master's degree programme is Dr Sudipto Das, the programme director, deputy dean of AI, Digital and Connected Health and senior lecturer in the school of Pharmacy and Biomolecular Sciences

The full time Masters course fuses the latest in genetic and genomics research with data analytics and computational biology, including programming, to give graduates the ability to analyse and interpret healthcare data. Graduates will also learn the impact of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning on drug discovery and the broader healthcare sector, as well as how to employ these tools and techniques to identify patterns in biological data sets. “These patterns will help us diagnose patients earlier, predict treatment response and tailor therapy accordingly,” says Dr Sudipto Das, programme director, School of Pharmacy and Biomolecular Sciences (PBS) at RCSI.

These critical skill sets are in high demand across an industry that is undergoing an evolution. The significant growth in the programme is in direct response to the demand for these skills, Das says.

According to Das, the sheer magnitude of this growth area cannot be understated as the health sector finally begins to utilise the breadth of data that is available. The market size for precision medicine was $102.17 billion (€99.40 billion) in 2024 but it is already projected that this will grow to $119 billion (€116 billion) in 2025.

READ MORE

With this exponential growth comes a deficit in the core skill sets that are required to make precision medicine a reality. The biological data scientists are the individuals who will analyse and interpret healthcare data to ultimately fill that gap between biological data collection and actual clinical decision-making, Das explains.

Dublin city centre campus of RCSI University of Medicine and Health Sciences

“The question asked nowadays on precision medicine is, ‘will this drug work in person A or person B?’ If you can identify this, then you can save the person unnecessary treatment and potential side effects, as well as costs to patients and the wider healthcare system,” he says. “Some patients will respond, others won’t and some might even develop adverse drug reactions. The reason for this disparity in response comes from the fact that everybody is unique.”

This makes clinical decision-making significantly more difficult but ultimately will lead to a better outcome, Das points out. “The gap must be filled by someone who understands the data, can analyse it and interpret it and effectively predict why they think ‘drug x’ may not work on a particular patient. This is the role of the biological data scientist and the master’s programme is aiming to give participants the skills to do exactly that.”

These newly-emerging experts will be pivotal in driving innovation in the coming years, says Das. “They will be identifying new ways of stratifying patients to tailored therapies and identifying biomarkers to determine response before we even commence treatment.” He also notes that course participants will learn to handle a wide variety of data types, not just that coming from biological samples, but also data from wearables and gadgets. “Digital and connected health is now huge. These biological data scientists will be sitting at the intersection of biology, computer sciences and statistics and playing a pivotal role.”

Indeed, a diverse range of graduates have entered the programme since its inception – from biology and science graduates to experts in computer science and data analysis.

A group of students graduate from the Masters Programme in Technologies and Analytics in Precision Medicine at RCSI

“The computer science graduates know how to analyse data and do the number crunching that is required but they don’t understand the biology so they come with their skill sets of coding and data analytics, but they then learn about the biological significance of this data and how to interpret it accordingly,” Das explains. “Similarly, the biological science graduates understand the health aspects but need to learn coding and data analysis. It is a pivotal programme in this sense, allowing post graduates to take their skill set and combine it with another for a high demand career.”

He adds that this role also carries a huge amount of purpose – analysing data with the end goal of improving patient outcomes and saving lives. “There is a huge translational aspect to this programme, in that we are putting the patient at the centre and that aligns with RCSI’s own ethos as a patient-centric health sciences university,” he explains.

The footprint of the pharma industry in Ireland continues to grow at a blistering pace with new biotech start-ups emerging, and long-established multinational pharma companies expanding their presence and investing heavily in their Irish sites. Das says graduates are already in high demand in an industry that is undergoing a significant shift in terms of innovation and drug discovery. “This is a future-focused programme in that the graduates will emerge ready to deal with these changes that are rapidly emerging in the healthcare landscape.”

Richard Kennedy global vice president and medical director of Almac Diagnostic Services

“Precision medicine and data analysis is the future of the pharmaceutical industry,” states Kennedy unequivocally.

Richard Kennedy is global vice-president and medical director of Almac Diagnostic Services, which is headquartered in Northern Ireland and has laboratory facilities across Europe, North America and partnership labs in APAC. He explains that he and his colleagues at Almac have worked closely with RCSI on the development of the MSc, helping to guide the topic selection for the curriculum and ensure it is “highly relevant” to industry. The organisation also offers industry project opportunities for the MScTAPM students.

“Precision medicine and data analysis is the future of the pharmaceutical industry,” states Kennedy unequivocally. “It’s also increasingly important from an economics point of view that we give the right treatments to the people who will respond best to them. This means people coming out of university now need to be able to analyse patient data, including biomarker test results, and apply artificial intelligence techniques that can better guide treatments. This will be huge in the next decade, so knowledge of it will be crucial.”

People with this specific skill set are currently in short supply across healthcare, adds Kennedy. “Within the industry at the moment there is definitely an unmet need for people who can understand and analyse these data as they pertain to health.”

An in-person open day for the MScTAPM programme will be held at RCSI, St Stephen’s Green, on February 1st, 2025. Register now at rcsi.com/mtapm

body.title: OpenAI’s o3 mini AI model is set for launch
body.description: The company announced it was testing advanced reasoning models, o3 and o3 mini, designed to address more complex tasks ...
body.article_content:
OpenAI, supported by Microsoft, is preparing to launch its latest reasoning AI model, the o3 mini, in early 2025.

OpenAI CEO Sam Altman confirmed this development via a post on the social media platform X.

The launch will include both the application programming interface (API) and an updated version of ChatGPT, according to Reuters.

The o3 mini model builds on the momentum of OpenAI’s previous releases.

In December 2024, the company announced it was testing advanced reasoning models, o3 and o3 mini, designed to address more complex tasks compared to earlier iterations.

These models aim to surpass their predecessors in domains such as science, mathematics, and coding.

In September 2024, OpenAI introduced its o1 AI models, which focused on tackling harder queries by allocating more time for processing.

At the time: “We have developed a new series of AI models designed to spend more time thinking before they respond. They can reason through complex tasks and solve harder problems than previous models in science, coding, and math.”

OpenAI’s advancements come amid increasing competition from tech giants such as Google and Apple.

Recently, the company unveiled a beta feature called Tasks for ChatGPT, marking its entry into the virtual assistant market alongside competitors like Apple’s Siri and Amazon’s Alexa.

ChatGPT's launch in late 2022 ignited a surge of investments in AI companies, with its rising popularity and product innovations enabling OpenAI to secure $6.6bn in funding.

Separately, OpenAI is training a new AI model called GPT-4b micro in collaboration with Retro Biosciences, a longevity science startup aiming to extend the human lifespan, reports the MIT Technology Review.

Backed by Altman Retro has been collaborating with OpenAI on this research for approximately a year.

The GPT-4b micro model focuses on re-engineering proteins, particularly the Yamanaka factors, which have the ability to transform human skin cells into stem cells with youthful characteristics.

"OpenAI’s o3 mini AI model is set for launch" was originally created and published by Verdict, a GlobalData owned brand.
